Topic.Title: should i reinvest dividend?

Message.Msg: I see nothing wrong with your reasoning...especially for a Long term investment. You save on having no brokerage fees for the Reinvestment, and over time, those 'fractional' shares add up nicely. And a Split would do nicely for you too. The lower share prices increase the fractional amount over time. I have a small holding of another stock, from many years ago, which started off with only 10 shares, and today it is over 50, due to reinvestment. Get it and forget it does pay off.

Topic.Title: CALL OPTION QUESTIONS

Message.Msg: Here are the answers: Call is a contract which gives you the right to buy stock. You don't have to buy stock when you buy call. Your gain on the call is only from the premium gain. You don't have to wait until expiration to sell call. You can take profit at anytime. Note that option expires on Sat, not on Friday, but the last day you can trade is Friday. If the call is in-the-money (stock price is higher than the strike price of the call) at the closing of the regular session on the expiration Friday, your broker will automatically exercise the right the call gives you and buy stock at the strike price on Sat. If you don't want to own stock for some reasons, you must tell your broker not to exercise it or sell the call before expiration. If the call is out-of-money (stock price is lower than the strike price of the call), it will be worthless after expiration. Unless you tell your broker to exercise it, your broker won't do anything and will just let it expires.

Topic.Title: should i reinvest dividend?

Message.Msg: No commission fees for divvy reinvestment. If you are truly going long term, this will be of benefit. And if the rumored Split occurs, you will be buying higher fractional shares, down the road, so it adds up even better. I have a smaller holding in another stock from years ago. Started off as about 10 shares (came about from another company buyout), and let the divvy reinvestment go on it, and today I have 50 shares. Not much, but it adds up. The get it and forget it can be rewarding. Good luck, and thanks for the topic.

Topic.Title: What is in it for Apple to Split the Stock, AND do Buybacks ?

Message.Msg: The ONLY reason to do a split would be to lower the stock price enough to join the Dow. stock over $200 are generally not added to the Dow because stocks are given weight by price on the Dow. Having said that, there is no reason to join the Dow. Someone stated on this board that of Apple moved to the Dow then funds would have to buy Apple stock. Well maybe but don't these funds already own Apple stock? I would think YES. What difference does it make if Apple is on the Nasdaq or the Dow? Do you really care?

Topic.Title: should i reinvest dividend?

Message.Msg: No brokerage commissions for Divvy reinvestment, and how about if Split occurs ? At lower share prices, the divvy will be buying 'larger' fractional share amounts. Soon you will be accumulating full share amounts. Of course, this is from the Long Term hold perspective.

Topic.Title: should i reinvest dividend?

Message.Msg: I am going to take the "reinvest dividends" option in my over-the-counter trading account. I believe this is a 'qualified dividend', meaning, I don't have to pay taxes until I actually sell the stock, at which time it's long term. In my tax-deferred account (IRA) I'm less worried about how the taxes pay out, since it's retirement and not subject to tax until I start withdrawing. So, in my IRA I'll take the cash, just to diversify a little, do something else, or just let it sit for a rainy day, next flash crash, etc... (I'll end up with about $2500 in cash in that account.)

Topic.Title: The biggest sleeper product that Apple is releasing imho is?

Message.Msg: More than that. A mini that weighs around 1/3 of a 10" iPad would be a far better ereader than the current iPad. 90% of the Kindle Fires I've seen in the wild are in the hands of children. In upper income families, Children start out with an iPod touch when they are 2 or 3, go to a full tablet when they're 10-12 and up. A 7" iPad would fill in the age 5 to 12 nicely. Just the right size and weight for those small hands. A 7" tablet is the size that would be ideal to keep in the car. It fits in the glove compartment, and would eliminate the need for a $2000 factory-installed GPS system, as well as providing Internet access on the go. With Siri integration coming to most car manufacturers, this alone could be a multi-million unit market for the 7" size iPad.

Topic.Title: What Happens to Apple Inc Share Price from Thursday August 10th till the Release of the iPhone 5?

Message.Msg: the way I understand it is that you must buy on or before the 8th (in-dividend date--this settles by the record date of the 13th--3 settling days with a weekend in between) the 13th (record dare) is when Apple looks to see who owns the stock on the 8th and they "record"--put these shareholders on record as owning. 9th is ex-dividend, the stock goes ex-dividend. Transactions made on the 9th, don`t settle and record until the 14th.

Topic.Title: What Happens to Apple Inc Share Price from Thursday August 10th till the Release of the iPhone 5?

Message.Msg: you don`t have to hold the stock during the 3 day settlement period you just have to own it on or before the in-dividend date ex-dividend date starts a new ball game

Topic.Title: Ex dividend is 8/13 not 8/9

Message.Msg: Record date is 8/13, but that is for settled trades. In order to be sure that all trades are settled properly, which can take several days, an ex-div date is set in advance. This means the transaction has to occur by this date. In this case, 8/9 is that day. Thompson

Topic.Title: CALL OPTION QUESTIONS

Message.Msg: And remember that if you buy a call, then exercise, the cost of the option is added to your basis. You will also have to get approval (at least with my broker) for different option transactions (e.g. covered call, buy call/put, straddles, etc.). Before you start trading them you really should go read some options educational web sites.

Topic.Title: Ex dividend is 8/13 not 8/9

Message.Msg: 8/9 IS the ex-date ! 8/13 is the date of record. If you are trading the stock, you must own it by the close of the ex-date and hold it through the record date to collect the dividend.

Message.Title: Stock Market Futures.....
Message.Msg: China’s stocks swung between gains and losses as concerns about the economy offset measures by regulators to encourage employees to buy shares in their own companies to bolster the equities market. The Shanghai Composite Index (SHCOMP) slipped 0.1 percent to 2,130.60 at 9:53 a.m. local time, erasing a gain of as much as 0.2 percent. The CSI 300 Index (SHSZ300) declined 0.1 percent to 2,350.41. The Bloomberg China-US 55 Index (CH55BN), the measure of the most-traded U.S.-listed Chinese companies, added 2 percent in New York. The securities regulator published draft rules that would allow publicly traded companies to pay as much as 30 percent of wages in stock, according to the draft posted on the China Securities Regulatory Commission’s website yesterday. Employees who receive shares as salaries or bonuses would have to hold them for at least 36 months, the CSRC said. “More listed companies and their employees will buy their own shares as stocks are pretty attractive especially in terms of dividend yields,” said Wu Kan, a Shanghai-based fund manager at Dazhong Insurance Co., which oversees $285 million. “Though the securities regulator is hammering out a spate of measures to support equities, the market focus is still on when economic growth will bottom and pick up.” The Shanghai index rose 0.2 percent last week, the first gain in seven weeks, after the securities regulator announced it will cut transaction fees by 20 percent.

Topic.Title: KCG Shareholders Really Got Boned Tonight...

Message.Msg: Electronic trader Knight Capital Group may get a lifeline of $400 million in capital from a new group of investors, according to a report by CNBC’s David Faber. The new investors may buy convertible preferred securities, that is, bond-like equity with an option to change to a set number of common shares at an established price and at an exercise date in the future. Knight’s buyers of preferred would have the right to purchase about 270 million shares of Knight common stock at $1.50 a share. On Friday, Knight’s shares closed at $4, down from $12 two weeks ago. The equity infusion could dilute existing common shareholders by perhaps 60%, but Knight’s viability as an on-going concern is questionable without it. The preferred securities deal could give Knight sufficient capital to open on Monday for trading, filling the hole caused by errant trades that created about $440 million in losses on Wednesday. When Knights new preferred shares convert to common, the number of common shares outstanding would jump to 370 million from 100 million. The conversion date could be within 10 days, according to CNBC. The preferred securities would yield 2%, generating some limited short-term income for the investors. Knight’s investor consortium includes: private-equity firms General Atlantic and Blackstone Group and brokerage firms TD Ameritrade and Stifel Nicolaus, said CNBC. Investment bank Jefferies & Co. may be the intermediary for sale. With heightened concern over the stability of high-frequency trading in the stock exchanges given the tumult of the Facebook IPO and the Flash Crash, the Knight investors face risks that Knight’s technical glitch may be the tip of the iceberg of many issues with the highly complicated trading algorithms. Goldman Sachs may be a major beneficiary of the Knight turmoil. Goldman could buy some of Knight’s inventory of 140 companies that it erroneously bought when its trading system got caught in a purchase loop, according to ZeroHedge. The Knight positions include many household names, like Alcoa and Verizon. On the morning of the trading disruption, Verizon, jumped from $44 to $47, for example. Goldman would pick up Knight’s inventory at fire sale prices without having to take on the risk of equity ownership in the exchange trader.
